coredata.dc:title: EXAFS studies with synchrotron radiation of polystyrene-ruthenium catalyst
coredata.dc:creator: Bianconi, A.

coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
The local structure of the metal-atom surroundings in polystyrene-ruthenium complexes (PSt-Ru) has been studied by EXAFS. EXAFS at the Ru K-edge (22,118 keV) has been measured for metallic Ru and PSt-Ru. Numerical elaboration of the data gives the Ru-C distance (d = 2.05 A) and the number of carbon atoms coordinated to the metal (coordination number 6) in PSt-Ru.

xocs:doc.xocs:rawtext: Volume 90, number 4 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 6 August 1982 EXAFS STUDIES WITH SYNCHROTRON RADIATION OF POLYSTYRENE-RUTHENIUM CATALYST A. BIANCONI, M. DELL'ARICCIA, A. GIOVANNELLI IStittito di Fisica, Uim'ersit3di Roma, Rome. Italy E. BURATTINI, N. CAVALLO. P. PATTERI, E. PANCtNI 1st i/uto di Fisica Spermentale, IfniversitS ds Napoliand MFN, Se:ione di Napolt, Via A Tori, 3. 80138 Naples. Italy C. CARUNI, F. CIARDELU, D. PAPESCHI, P. PERTICI, G. VITOLU Centm di Studio del CNR per Ie Macromolecole Stereordusate ed Otticameme Attwe. Isluuw di Cininica O/ganica Industrials, UmversitS di Pisa, Via Risorgimenlo. 35, 56100 Pisa, lialy G. DALBA, P. FORNASINI Dipwtimento di Fiska, Libera University di Trento, Povo, Trento. Italy and S. MOBIUO and L. PALLADINO PVLS-INFN, Lcboratori ffa:mnah diFmscari. Frascali, Rome, Italy Received 31 May 1982 The local structure of the metal-atom surroundings in polystyrene-ruthenium complexes (PSt-Ru) has been studied by EXAFS. EXAFS at the Ru K-edge (22.118 keV) has been measured fonnetallic Ru and PSt-Ru. Numerical elaboration of the data gives the Ru-C distance (d = 2.05 A) and the number of carbon atoms coordinated to the metal (coordination number 6) in PSt-Ru. 1. Introduction Extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) [1] is a powerful tool for structural studies of non- crystalline materials. A very interesting application is offered by the structural analysis of homogeneous metal complexes supported on polymers, for which it is very difficult to obtain structural information [2]. Polymer—metal complexes are prepared by the re- action of a transiBon-raetal complex and an inso- luble polymeric support and can act as heterogenized catalysis in several reactions of industrial interest [3]. Moreover these systems can display in some cases ex- ceptional catalytic properties with respect to the un- supported monomeric analogs. A remarkable example is offered by polystyrene—ruthenium complexes (PSt-Ru) prepared by reacting Ru(COT)(COD) (COT = Ti6 -cycloocta-1,3,5-triene;COD = t^-cycloocta- 1,5-diene) with polystyrene (PSt) under a hydrogen atmosphere (p^ = I atm) at 20°C in tetrahydrofiiran (scheme I, step a) [7]. Using monomeric aromatic derivatives the same reaction gives arene—ruthenium complexes of the type Ru^S-arene^COD) (scheme I, step b) [4,5]. 0009-2614/82/0000-OOOO/S 02.75 © 1982 North-Holland 257 Volume 90, number 4 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 6 August 1982 The PSt-Ru complexes show catalytic activity in the hydrogenation, under relatively mild conditions (PH, = 50 atm, T= 20-80°C), of a wide range ofun- saturated substrates such as olefins, aromatic hydro- carbons, ketones, oximes, nitro derivatives, whereas the monomeric complexes, acting in solution, are on- ly active for olefin hydrogenation [4-6]. Elemental analysis, IR and mass spectra indicate that the PSt-Ru complexes do not contain the cyclo- olelm ligands initially present in the Ru(COT)(COD) compound, which are probably displaced by the phe- nyl rings of the polystyrene. In order to obtain more detailed information on the metal environment in these compounds and par- ticularly on the presence ofarene-ruthenium bonds, an EXAFS analysis was affected on the PSt-Ru com- plex having a phenyl/ruthenium molar ratio n = 2. 2. Experimental The EXAFS measurements have been performed at the Wiggler Facility of the National Laboratories in Frascati. The synchrotron radiation was generated by a transverse Wiggler magnet installed on the ADONE storage ring [7]. The X-ray beam was monochroma- tized by a channel-cut silicon (111) single crystal. The total energy resolution of the apparatus ^4.5 eV at the K-edge of Ru, mainly due to the intrinsic resolu- tion of the crystal and the angular vertical divergence of the beam. The step width of tlie rotating table was =^43 eV, corresponding to rotation steps of 0.001°. The detection system consisted of two ionization chambers filled with argon. The whole apparatus was remotely controlled by means ofaPDP 11/40 com- puter. In order to optimize the signal-to-noise ratio a val- ue of (ix = 2 was chosen for the sample thickness PSt-Ru. This complex was prepared as described in the lit- erature [4] from atactic polystyrene (A?y = 86000) and from Ru(COT)(COD) [8]. Ru metal, Fluka prod- uct, with purity larger than 99.9% was used. The sam- ples of PSt—Ru and Ru consisted of fine powders en- closed between two adhesive Kapton tapes in order to protect them from moisture and to form a uniform very thin Film. 3. Results The K-edge X-ray absorption spectra (XAS) of me- tallic ruthenium and PSt—Ru are reported in figs. 1 and 2. Two energy regions must be distinguished, the so called "EXAFS region", for E-Ey over «40 eV, and the "EXAFS region", for E - EQ below "40 eV [9, 10]. The XANES features are due to multiple scattering resonances and therefore their intensities and energy positions are determined both by the relative positions of many atoms around the absorbing one and by the type of atoms (Ru or Q. The different XANES fea- tures in the spectra of Ru metal and PSt-Ru show immediately that both type and geometrical coordi- nation of atoms around the Ru atom are different in the two systems. The strong multiple scattering reso- nances A in the PSt sample (fig. 2) should be due to C atoms in the fust coordination shell which have their backscattering amplitude at low kinetic energy of the photoelectron. This is confirmed by the EXAFS analysis. Indeed the Fourier transform indicates (fig. 3a) that the Ru-Ru distance is ^23 A, thus the peak at 1.34 A (fig. 3b) in PSt-Ru should be assigned to the Ru-C distance which is expected to be shorter than the Ru-Ru distance [11]. The second peak at 2.56 A in the spectrum of the complex (fig. 3b) can then tentatively be assigned to the Ru atoms in the .4 x < _I——L_|——]—i—1_ 2Z300 22800 E.«V Fig. 1. K-cdge X-ray absorption spectrum (XAS) of the poly- styrene-ruthenium complex with a phenyl group to rutheni- um ratio (n) equal to 1 second coordination shell. Ru-Ru and Ru-C dis- tances have been determined on the basis of the best fitting of EXAFS oscillations. The EXAFS of the first Fig. 3. Fourier transform of EXAFS spectra for metallic Ru (a) and PSt-Ru (b). coordination shell is given by the equation: fcx(fe) = (AW^expC-lJkV)^) Xsin[2&/?+0^)+^(fc)-n], (1) where k is the photoelectron wavevector, o2 is the Debye-Waller factor, and N is the coordination num- ber. Metallic ruthenium was used as a model com- pound to check the calculated phase shift (^, + ^) and amplitude [/l(fc)] [12]. Fig. 4 shows the comparison of the EXAFS spec- trum calculated by eq. (I) with the experimental back transform of the main peak in the Fourier transform of Ru from Fig. 3a, indicating that good agreement is obtained (fig. 4) with a Ru-Ru mean'distance of 2.68 A, coordination number (CN) of 12 and o2 = 0.0037 A2. This good agreement allows us to use the amplitude A(k) and the central-atom phase shift 0g of Ru for unknown compounds. The Ru-C distance of PSt—Ru has been obtained by fitting the experi- mental EXAFS spectrum with two shells, the former of carbon atoms and the latter of Ru. For the first K,*' Fig. 4. Calculated and experimental EXAFS for (a) metallic Ru and (b) PSt-Ru complex. 259 Volume 90, number 4 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 6 August 1982 shell we have used the 0g of Ru as checked and <t>^ taken from ref. [12]. In the fitting procedure a ruthenium-carbon distance Ru-C of 2.05 ± 0.05 A and CNof6±l was obtained with a Ru-Ru distance of 2.88 ±0.1 A. The number of coordinated Ru atoms cannot be accurately determined because of the noise in the spec- trum, the best Fit giving CN = 2 ± 2. heterogeneous catalysts obtained by the attachment of transition-metal complexes to polymeric ligands. Further studies are in progress on complexes with different phenyl/Ru ratio before and after catalysis as well as on model compounds, such as the 1,3- diphenylpropane—Ru complex [4]. References 4. Discussion These results are consistent with the presence of Ru atoms complexed to a single phenyl ring of the polystyrene side chains, excluding bis-arene systems. Indeed the Ru—C distance determined in PSt—Ru is in good agreement with the typical Ru—C distances in homogeneous monomeric Ru—arene complexes [13]. Moreover, accepting the hypothesis of Ru at- oms in tlie second shell, the Ru-Ru distance found (2.88 A) is similar to that found in small (CN = 6) ruthenium clusters containing bonded arenes [14] and appreciably different from that of metallic Ru (2.68 A) [11]. Even if these results are to be considered as prelim- inary, they allow us to hypothesize for PSt—Ru com- plexes a structure in which small Ru clusters are at- tached to polystyrene by complexation of Ru atoms to a single phenyl ring. This is consistent with the vari- able stoichiometry of these systems, obtained starting with a different PSt-Ru(COT)(COD) weight ratio, and with IR spectra indicating the presence of uncoor- dinated phenyl groups [4]. Moreover the presence of clusters and coordinative- ly unsaturated Ru atoms allows us to explain the bet- ter catalytic properties of PSt—Ru with respect to RuOjS-arene^COD) complexes [4-6]. Finally, these findings confirm that EXAFS is a useful technique for understanding the structure of [11 F.W. Lytle, G.H. Via and J H. Smfeld, in: Synchrotron radiation research, cds H. Wmick and D. ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: The local structure of the metal-atom surroundings in polystyrene-ruthenium complexes (PSt-Ru) has been studied by EXAFS. EXAFS at the Ru K-edge (22,118 keV) has been measured for metallic Ru and PSt-Ru. Numerical elaboration of the data gives the Ru-C distance (d = 2.05 A) and the number of carbon atoms coordinated to the metal (coordination number 6) in PSt-Ru.
